articles.headline: Now Narrating the Olympics: A.I.-Al Michaels
articles.snippet: NBC will offer a customized, daily highlight reel with A.I.-generated narration that sounds like the longtime broadcaster.
articles.abstract: NBC will offer a customized, daily highlight reel with A.I.-generated narration that sounds like the longtime broadcaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Olympics have ancient beginnings. Now, they will also have a dose of the latest technology.

articles.headline: Prominent Lawyer Roberta Kaplan Departs Firm After Clash With Colleagues
articles.snippet: The well-connected attorney, who founded a powerhouse firm at the dawn of the #MeToo era, has faced complaints that she mistreated and insulted other lawyers.
articles.abstract: The well-connected attorney, who founded a powerhouse firm at the dawn of the #MeToo era, has faced complaints that she mistreated and insulted other lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roberta A. Kaplan, the celebrated lawyer who took on former President Donald J. Trump, and helped win marriage equality for gay Americans, is stepping down from the law firm she founded after clashing with her partners over her treatment of colleagues.
articles.byline: By Katie J. M. Baker and David Enrich

articles.headline: New Tactic in China’s Information War: Harassing a Critic’s Child in the U.S.
articles.snippet: A covert campaign to target a writer critical of the country’s Communist Party has extended to sexually suggestive threats against his 16-year-old daughter.
articles.abstract: A covert campaign to target a writer critical of the country’s Communist Party has extended to sexually suggestive threats against his 16-year-old daughter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deng Yuwen, a prominent Chinese writer who now lives in exile in the suburbs of Philadelphia, has regularly criticized China and its authoritarian leader, Xi Jinping. China’s reaction of late has been severe, with crude and ominously personal attacks online.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: From Hacker to Hunted Figure, the Polarizing Legacy of Julian Assange
articles.snippet: The co-founder of WikiLeaks was a heroic crusader for truth to many people for publishing government secrets. To others, he was a reckless leaker endangering lives.
articles.abstract: The co-founder of WikiLeaks was a heroic crusader for truth to many people for publishing government secrets. To others, he was a reckless leaker endangering lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his two-decade odyssey from Australian hacker to new-age media celebrity, hunted figure, perennial prisoner and finally, a free man, Julian Assange has always been easier to caricature than characterize.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Megan Specia

articles.headline: Boeing Angers Safety Officials With Disclosures on 737 Max Incident
articles.snippet: The National Transportation Safety Board said Boeing had improperly released information about the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines flight.
articles.abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said Boeing had improperly released information about the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing drew fresh criticism from a federal regulator on Thursday over disclosures about the continuing investigation into a harrowing January flight during which one of the company’s 737 Max planes lost a panel, exposing passengers to howling winds at an altitude of about 16,000 feet.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Mark Walker

articles.headline: How to Escape From the Russian Army
articles.snippet: Facing grim job prospects, a young Nepali signed up to join Russia’s military, which sent him to fight in Ukraine. His ordeal of combat, injury and escape turned into a tale worthy of Hollywood.
articles.abstract: Facing grim job prospects, a young Nepali signed up to join Russia’s military, which sent him to fight in Ukraine. His ordeal of combat, injury and escape turned into a tale worthy of Hollywood.
articles.byline: By Bhadra Sharma and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Supreme Court Jeopardizes Opioid Deal, Rejecting Protections for Sacklers
articles.snippet: The justices rejected a bankruptcy settlement maneuver that would have protected members of the Sackler family from civil claims related to the opioid epidemic.
articles.abstract: The justices rejected a bankruptcy settlement maneuver that would have protected members of the Sackler family from civil claims related to the opioid epidemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court said on Thursday that members of the Sackler family cannot be shielded from liability for civil claims related to the opioid epidemic, jeopardizing a bankruptcy plan that would have offered such protection in exchange for channeling billions of dollars toward addressing the crisis.

articles.headline: Russia Sends Waves of Troops to the Front in a Brutal Style of Fighting
articles.snippet: More than 1,000 Russian soldiers in Ukraine were killed or wounded on average each day in May, according to NATO and Western military officials.
articles.abstract: More than 1,000 Russian soldiers in Ukraine were killed or wounded on average each day in May, according to NATO and Western military officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: May was a particularly deadly month for the Russian army in Ukraine, with an average of more than 1,000 of its soldiers injured or killed each day, according to U.S., British and other Western intelligence agencies.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Marc Santora
